Label: HP
Isolation Source: the oral cavity; however it has not been proven genetically
Isolation Comments: derived from the oral cavity; however it has not been proven genetically
Comments: Some pathogens in pyothorax or pulmonary abscess is thought to be derived from the oral cavity; however it has not been proven genetically. In this study, we examined genetic homology using a next-generation sequencer. In National Hospital Organization of Himeji Medical Center, subsequent patients with pulmonary abscess or pyothorax were recruited. Oral bacterial flora was obtained by wiping the oral cavity. Pus was collected by percutaneous needle aspiration and cultured. The isolated strain was identified based on 16S rRNA. We limited genetic homology study to the species which have genome information disclosed on the internet to design the isolated strain-specific primer. We also limited the homology study to the strains which contained **>= copies/ml of oral sample enough for PCR. The whole genome of the isolated strain was sequenced using an Illumina Miseq sequencer. We designed 5 sets of isolated strain-specific primers compared with the genome information of the same species on the internet. Total DNA of oral bacterial flora was amplified by PCR using these primers, and the sequence of the amplicons was analyzed for the homology. Between Aug 1, 2013, and Mar 27, 2015, 42 patients were recruited. **4 patients with pulmonary abscess and 4 with pyothorax were eligible for genetic homology test. Streptococcus anginosus group (n=6), Parvimonas micra (n=1), and Fusobacterium nucleatum (n=1) were isolated from pus. In all patients, all amplified sequences in oral bacterial flora completely matched the genome sequence of the isolated strain, but did not perfectly match the genome for the same species in database disclosed on the internet. To our knowledge, this is the first report proving that bacteria isolated from pulmonary abscess or pyothorax are identical to oral bacteria at the strain level based on genetic homology.

Label: NHP
Comments: We introduce a comprehensive library of human gut bacteria: a library of 7,758 bacterial isolates, characterized by 16S sanger sequences, which were obtained from healthy FMT donors recruited in the Boston area. This library covers most of the phylogenetic diversity found in the human gut and contains extensive strain diversity. Isolates can be requested at this address: XXX.We report Whole Genome Sequences (WGSs) for a phylogenetically-comprehensive subset of these isolates, representing a library of 3,632 WGSs, to enable researchers to test and predict phenotypes in vitro and in vivo. We also provide longitudinal 16S (1,169 samples from 90 donors), metagenomic (564 samples from 84 donors) and metabolomic data (179 samples from 83 donors) for a large cohort of FMT donors.

Label: HP
Comments: The incidence of Non Tuberculous Mycobacteria (NTM) is reported regularly from different parts of India. Nearly one-third of known Mycobacterium species have been observed to be associated with disease in humans. There are some species which primarily affect the respiratory system and cause disease resembling tuberculosis (TB). Risk factors for NTM pulmonary disease include prior TB, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cystic fibrosis, occupational lung disease etc. The important feature of NTM infection is, essentially all NTMs are resistant to all first-line anti TB drugs and to some second-line injectables. Another aspect is NTM infections initially are treated as TB and are correctly diagnosed very late during the deterioration stage. Hence it is imperative to detect and identify NTM species at the earliest so as to reduce the NTM associated morbidity and mortality.

Label: NHP
Isolation Comments: isolated from healthy and BV microbiomes
Comments: Lactobacillus crispatus is a dominant organism in a healthy vaginal microbial flora. A pathological state of the vaginal flora is known as Bacterial Vaginosis (BV). The microbiome under BV is very diverse, and this state can cause several complaints and problems. The etiology of BV is unknown. Although L. crispatus is often present at low frequencies in the BV vaginal microbiome, it apparently cannot become dominant in the population, as in a healthy microbiome. A possible explanation would be that L. crispatus in BV microbiomes differs genetically from L. crispatus in healthy vaginal microbiomes. To find support for this hypothesis we will reconstruct and compare genomic sequences of L. crispatus strains isolated from healthy and BV microbiomes.Researchers at GGD Amsterdam and TNO Zeist investigate phenotypic differences of the same strains. Our task will be to provide these researchers with supporting data and leads for investigation.

Label: HP
Isolation Comments: isolated from urine samples in Myanmar
Comments: Emergence and spread of metallo beta lactamase producing Pseudomonas species isolates have been become a serious problem in medical settings worldwide. The Pseudomonas spp. belonging to the Pseudomonas putida group is closely related to Pseudomonas monteilii and P. putida. The species is assumed to be a human pathogen because these isolates were obtained from patients with diarrhea or urinary tract infection. We sequenced eight strains isolated from urine samples in Myanmar. These stains were multidrug-resistant strains. The definition of multidrug-resistant strain is that it shows no susceptibility to at least one agent in more than three antimicrobial categories. In this study, we sequenced these strains with Illumina MiSeq and Oxford Nanopore MinION. The sequence data was used for searching drug resistance genes. We checked the location of resistant genes and genomic environments surrounding the genes. And the sequence data was used for phylogenyetic analysis based on whole genomic information.

Label: HP
Comments: Chronic otitis media with effusion is one of the most common childhood diseases in developed countries and is responsible for a significant proportion of hearing loss in children. The disease is caused by microbial biofilms in the middle ear, which trigger the release of effusion fluid. The portal of entry for bacteria to reach the middle ear is not well understood. One possibility is that bacteria transcend the eustacian tube from the adenoids. Here, we isolated strains of Streptococcus spp. from paired middle ear effusion fluid and adenoid samples of two patients. The paired samples from each patient were identified as the same species by MALDI-TOF. In one case, paired isolates were classified as S. oralis, and in the other the isolates were both S. parasanguinis. The genome sequencing project aimed to (i) confirm the species identifications assigned by MALDI-TOF and (ii) determine whether paired isolates were the same strain.

Label: HP
Isolation Comments: isolated from human blood samples and patients with implant-associated infections
Comments: A previously unrecognized, slow-growing, anaerobic staphylococcal species was identified, isolated from human blood samples and patients with implant-associated infections. Seven strains were genome sequenced. Phylogenomic analyses showed that this newly identified species forms a separate clade within coagulase-negative staphylococci; closest relatives are Staphylococcus saccharolyticus and Staphylococcus capitis with an average nucleotide identity of 80%. We propose to name the new species “Staphylococcus nericia”.

Label: HP
Comments: This project consists of a two-phase action plan designed to validate the overall aims of the GAS vaccinology programme as well as generating publishable units from scientifically robust comparisons. Apart from vaccine antigen design, this programme of sequencing will support targeted analyses of specific disease associations and global transmission patterns of prominent sequence types- all ongoing sequencing based research foci that Sanger (Mark Davies) is currently analysing. PHASE 1. Hi-seq (n=750), Pacbio (n=30) and RNA-seq (n=48) Hi-seq (750) We currently have a collection of 750 genomes extracted and ready for Hi-seq (objective 1) - 90 South China and North China (15 emm types, 10 years) - 50 South America (40 emm types, 14 years) - 210 Southern Europe and Northern Europe (30 emm types, 10 years) - 50 South and North India (29 emm types, 5 years) - 350 New Zealand (53 emm types, 13 years) The sampling strategy is based on epidemiological (emm) patterns, temporal and clinical relevance in order to provide significant representation from all continents and all GAS clinical manifestations. Two things to reiterate: 1. The geographical and spatial epidemiology of GAS varies. Deep sampling is required for informed global vaccine design. page 1 [A5] Please state all collaborating PIs (and name of Institution) [A7] Is this a joint project with another Sanger PI, if so state name(s) [A9] Does this project use samples? [A10] Please choose which types of sample you will be using 2. The geographical locations being sampled are also being targeted as sites for future vaccine trials. A baseline understanding of genetic stability is required for genomic epidemiological surveillance. This data is part of a pre-publication release. For information on the proper use of pre-publication data shared by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute please see http://www.sanger.ac.uk/datasharing/

Label: HP
Isolation Comments: isolated in Bangladesh and is now rarely isolated elsewhere
Comments: BACKGROUND: Cholera is endemic in Bangladesh, with outbreaks reported annually. Currently, the majority of epidemic cholera reported globally is El Tor biotype Vibrio cholerae isolates of the serogroup O1. However, in Bangladesh, outbreaks attributed to V. cholerae serogroup O139 isolates, which fall within the same phylogenetic lineage as the O1 serogroup isolates, were seen between 1992 and 1993 and in 2002 to 2005. Since then, V. cholerae serogroup O139 has only been sporadically isolated in Bangladesh and is now rarely isolated elsewhere. METHODS: Here, we present case histories of four cholera patients infected with V. cholerae serogroup O139 in 2013 and 2014 in Bangladesh. We comprehensively typed these isolates using conventional approaches, as well as by whole genome sequencing. Phenotypic typing and PCR confirmed all four isolates belonging to the O139 serogroup. FINDINGS: Whole genome sequencing revealed that three of the isolates were phylogenetically closely related to previously sequenced El Tor biotype, pandemic 7, toxigenic V. cholerae O139 isolates originating from Bangladesh and elsewhere. The fourth isolate was a non-toxigenic V. cholerae that, by conventional approaches, typed as O139 serogroup but was genetically divergent from previously sequenced pandemic 7 V. cholerae lineages belonging to the O139 or O1 serogroups. CONCLUSION: These results suggest that previously observed lineages of V. cholerae O139 persist in Bangladesh and can cause clinical disease and that a novel disease-causing non-toxigenic O139 isolate also occurs. This data is part of a pre-publication release. For information on the proper use of pre-publication data shared by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute (including details of any publication moratoria), please see http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/who-we-are/policies/open-access-science http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/downloads/bacteria/

Label: HP
Isolation Comments: isolated from these samples and compared to clinical samples of Legionella pneumophila from Michigan hospitals
Comments: Tap water samples were collected from homes, businesses, and hospitals in Genesee County, Michigan. Legionella pneumophila was isolated from these samples and compared to clinical samples of Legionella pneumophila from Michigan hospitals. The dataset also includes positive and negative controls submitted as QA/QC and non-Legionella strains isolated using the standard methods for Legionella isolation and are relevant for consideration of the potential false positives that can be produced from these methods.

Comments: This study aimed to use Illumina sequencing to generate whole genome sequencing data for a clinical isolate of Pandoraea apista from a patient with cystic fibrosis. We aimed to compare our whole genome data with existing whole genomes to examine variation in gene content and to search for novel antimicrobial resistance genes, or mechanisms of resistance.
